title: How many viewers will tune in to watch Sunday Night Football on 29 October 2017?
possible_answers: More than 15 million but less than 15.5 million
preds: I'm going low, just haven't seen any buzz about it on the social internets
Interested in trying a forecasting model.
The Patriots are not featured. Neither are the Cowboys. And this is one heck of a World Series.

Pittsburgh Steelers vs Detroit Lions Competing with Game 5 of World Series.  Steelers really draw an audience. They have done very well for CBS in games against Cincinnati and Kansas City. They have been drawing audiences comparable to New England, Dallas, Green Bay. These numbers include streaming, so you have to subtract a couple million:
http://www.sportsmediawatch.com/nfl-tv-ratings-viewership-nbc-cbs-fox-espn-nfln-regular-season-playoffs/
trying to extrapolate the past numbers to future numbers

Smaller markets than some recent forecasts, and competing with MLB World Series at same time which has bigger market teams. Amory10 made me consider last years Sunday night competition, noting the high SNF viewership despite the World Series, but yr/yr NFL has 7% decrease in viewership.
We have Halloween on one hand and a widespread duck hunting weather...
Forget football.  Baseball, hockey and basketball will be moving in on that fan territory.

Guessing low end.  These are not particularly big-market teams, it's a bit into the season so the thrill is wearing off, and the Lions are not having a breathtaking year.  On the other hand, I know little about this sport and care even less, so it would be well to pay no attention to anythIng I say about it.

Hard to say.  Last year, when Sunday Night Football aired at the same time as Game 5 of the World Series, SNF had 16.825m viewers (http://thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2016/10/31/sundays-broadcast-ratings-fox-world-series-upset-nbc-sunday-night-football-963012/broadcast_20161030/)...which is to say, I'm not convinced the World Series will be a huge drag on SNF viewership.  If we take this year's numbers as 'base rates,' then...  4/7 (or *roughly* 60%) were below 16 million, so I tried to distribute that 60% across the first 4 answer options. I can't figure out how to discriminate with any precision between those bins.  3/7 (or roughly 43%) were above 16million.

Starting with a low estimate here. It's the Steelers and Lions on SNF. While both teams have their dedicated fan bases, it's not necessarily a must-watch match-up. Beyond the normal Sunday programming, there's the Season Finale of the The Deuce on HBO (season finales tend to draw more viewership from what I can tell). But perhaps more importantly, and what is most affecting my forecast, is that Game 5 of the World Series is scheduled for Sunday night at the same time. Looking at the viewership of the World Series, comparing that to the viewership of SNF, and recognizing that some of those same sports fans will have to choose between the two programs, I think SNF ends up losing viewership. After all, it's just Week 8 in the NFL, and while both teams are playing to improve their divisional rankings and thus guarantee a playoff spot, it will not likely compete with the championship series for the MLB. And Game 5 could be the deciding game if either LA or Houston sweep the other in Games 3 and 4 (series tied at 1-1).  So yeah, the World Series will pull viewership away from SNF, which will already be competing with the normal Sunday night programming.
